Wallace Warrior.Action: Father tells young William to stay behind for safety, showing protective care.
Malcolm Wallace shows anger and sorrow at the sight of murdered neighbors, indicating empathy and shared grief.
Observes the deserted MacAndrews farm and investigates cautiously with his father, showing awareness and prudence.
Enters the barn and discovers the hanging bodies, reacting with shock but maintaining composure alongside his father.
Follows his father through the barn to inspect the scene carefully, demonstrating attentiveness and presence of mind.
Allows young William to enter the dangerous barn area despite earlier instructions to stay behind, indicating a lapse in judgment or control.
No direct action or statement by Wallace Warrior in this excerpt; the focus is on his family members' reactions and trauma.
Malcolm Wallace kneels to look into William's eyes and says 'I love ya, boy. You stay.'
William insists 'I can fight' despite being told to stay, showing determination but also respect when he ultimately stays.
Malcolm Wallace encourages fighting to show they are men, not dogs, inspiring and rallying the farmers.
Eavesdrops on his father's planning, showing curiosity and awareness of the situation.
Insists he can fight despite being told to stay behind, demonstrating confidence and willingness to participate.
Is left behind by his father who emphasizes the importance of wits over brute force, indicating Wallace's youth and inexperience.
Looks forlorn after being told to stay, showing emotional vulnerability but also respect for his father's decision.
Cooks stew and sets out two bowls, hoping for company.
Pulls back Hamish to avoid premature confrontation with soldiers.
Waits alone, leaving a candle burning beside the stew.
Pulls Hamish back to avoid premature action, showing caution and tactical patience.
Plans to confront the English soldiers the next day, indicating resolve and forward thinking.
Leaves a candle burning beside the stew, hoping for his familyâ€™s return, showing a mix of hope and practical preparation.
Stays awake all night, afraid to sleep, showing vigilance but also anxiety.
Peers around the tree and assesses the situation, identifying the threat as English soldiers.
Eats alone quietly, showing no outward anger or blame despite tragedy.
Approaches the bodies of his father and brother with solemnity and respect.
Eats alone quietly and continues daily chores despite emotional distress.
Observes the arrival of the bodies calmly and processes the grim news without panic.
Approaches the bodies in the shed despite the emotional difficulty, showing resolve.
No indication of taking any action to change or influence the situation at this point; mostly passive.
Accepts a small gesture of kindness from a young girl (the Scottish thistle) and shares a moment of silent connection with her.
Stands alone in grief, isolated from neighbors who avoid adopting or supporting him.
No direct interaction with others beyond silent grief; neighbors and family show little warmth toward him.
Stands alone at the graveside of his family, showing quiet resilience despite deep grief.
Is perceived by neighbors as a grieving, rebellious boy not yet ready to be a leader.
Shows no direct interaction in this excerpt; Argyle acts protectively and with some warmth toward William, but Wallace's warmth is not demonstrated here.
Leans down over William with great tenderness and kisses his nephew on the hair.
Moves through the night, barefoot and in nightshirt, drawn by the sound of bagpipes to the graveyard to witness a solemn gathering.
Whispers to his uncle, showing curiosity and a desire to understand the grief and rituals of his community.
Despite his grief and vulnerability, seeks connection with his uncle and the community's mourning, indicating sincerity and openness.
Despite grief and fear, wakes up and actively searches for his uncle, showing initiative and determination.
Moves barefoot and in nightshirt toward the graveyard at night, drawn by the sound of bagpipes, showing courage and resolve despite vulnerability.
Stops briefly upon realizing he is heading to the graveyard but forces himself onward, demonstrating self-control and purposeful action.
Whispers a question to his uncle about the gathering, showing curiosity and desire to understand the situation.
Sits his horse confidently with a straight back and relaxed hands, projecting lean, rippled power and a dangerous presence.
Reaches out calmly to retrieve his bird from the soldiers after being harassed.
Contributes his goose to the communal feast.
Nods and greets farm women politely, acknowledging them sincerely.
Calmly handles intimidation by English soldiers without escalating conflict, confidently retrieves his goose despite their harassment.
Demonstrates awareness of social dynamics by acknowledging farm women and contributing to the feast, showing social intelligence and confidence.
Takes the hand of a disappointed girl and gives her a respectful bow.
Acknowledges an old friend (Hamish) despite the challenge.
Avoids escalating conflict by conceding the challenge verbally before it turns physical.
Engages in a physical contest after being attacked, showing resilience but also respect for the challenge.
Acknowledges others' efforts and impresses people with his own skill.
Remains calm and unflinching despite provocation, showing confidence without hostility.
Engages in competitive banter but does not escalate conflict or insult others.
Throws a heavy stone farther than others, impressing the crowd.
Remains calm and confident when challenged, showing no fear even when a stone is thrown near him.
Uses a small stone casually to demonstrate confidence and unshakable composure.
Throws a rock to playfully knock Hamish down, then helps him up and shares a friendly embrace.
Passes Marion to dance with a girl with missing teeth, showing inclusiveness and kindness.
Throws a rock double the distance of a competitor and hits him accurately, knocking him down.
Calmly and confidently interacts with others, including helping Hamish up and engaging in social dancing.
Passes Marion to dance with another girl, showing social confidence and decisiveness.
Stands silently in the rain after the nobleman's abuse, keeping his thoughts to himself.
Politely asks to speak with Marion and invites her for a ride despite her parents' disapproval.
Remains standing alone in the rain, silently contemplating the injustice just witnessed, showing emotional resilience and internal processing.
Approaches the MacClannough house unannounced and confidently requests to speak with Marion, demonstrating social boldness and initiative.
Invites Marion for a ride despite her parents' disapproval, showing confidence and willingness to take social risks.
Does not intervene physically or verbally to stop the nobleman's abuse of prima noctes, potentially indicating restraint or lack of immediate action.
Invites Marion for a ride despite her mother's disapproval.
Thanks Marion for accepting his invitation and shows appreciation.
Helps Marion down from the horse and looks into her eyes, showing attentiveness and care.
Leaves Marion a dried thistle wrapped in flannel as a meaningful token.
Invites Marion for a ride despite potential disapproval, showing confidence and decisiveness.
Carefully helps Marion off the horse and maintains respectful behavior, demonstrating social awareness and skill.
Leaves Marion a meaningful token (dried thistle) instead of forcing a kiss, showing emotional intelligence and thoughtful restraint.
Insists on living in peace and raising a family despite pressure to join secret meetings and conflicts.
Shares a tender moment with Marion, showing affection and playfulness.
Refuses to be drawn into conflict and focuses on peaceful farming and family life despite pressure from others.
Does not respond aggressively or strategically to threats or warnings from MacClannough and others, simply returns to roof repair.
Expresses deep love and commitment to Marion, proposing marriage sincerely and promising to be with her forever.
Acknowledges Marion's fear and reassures her gently, showing sensitivity to her feelings.
Pledges lifelong love sincerely to Marion during the wedding ceremony.
Watches Marion with deep affection and emotion, showing genuine tenderness.
Initially reacts with defensive readiness to the unknown figure at the church door but is restrained by the priest's trust.
Watches Marion lovingly and savors her beauty, shares a playful and tender moment with her.
Intervenes violently to stop the assault on Marion, fights off multiple soldiers to protect her.
Throws Marion onto a horse to help her escape danger.
Intervenes decisively to stop the assault, uses physical skill to disable multiple attackers, and rescues Marion by quickly mounting her on a horse and escaping.
Darts off through the crowd, uses the environment skillfully to evade soldiers, and successfully escapes into the trees.
Pauses briefly in the central street to ensure he is spotted before changing direction, showing tactical awareness.
Knocks over baskets and jumps carts to slow pursuers, demonstrating quick thinking and resourcefulness.
Heads deeper into the trees expecting to find Marion but does not find her, indicating a possible oversight or misjudgment.
Fights fiercely for his people, inspiring loyalty.
Does not intervene or prevent Marion's capture and execution in this excerpt.
His ally Marion is captured and executed while he is not present to intervene.
Listens carefully for Marion but only hears the wind, showing awareness and caution.
Charges alone against twenty armed soldiers, showing fearless determination to protect his village.
Leads the fight to defend his people, inspiring others to join and overwhelm the enemy.
Leads and fights alongside farmer neighbors and villagers against soldiers.
Stops and pursues the fleeing Magistrate who pleads for mercy.
Drags the Magistrate by his hair and kills him despite his pleas for mercy.
Hamish puts a hand on Wallace's shoulder; Wallace looks at him but looks away, showing his grief and emotional distance after killing the Magistrate.
Kills the Magistrate decisively and swiftly, demonstrating skill and resolve.
Sits alone, staring at nothing after the killing, showing emotional struggle but no immediate action.
Tells MacGregor and his men to go home to protect themselves, showing concern for their safety.
Stops the archer from killing Lord Bottoms, demonstrating mercy and restraint despite Bottoms' cruelty.
Leads a surprise attack on the English stronghold, coordinating a swift and effective assault that overwhelms the enemy with minimal resistance.
Calmly stops an archer from killing Lord Bottoms at the last moment, showing control and strategic restraint.
Tells MacGregor and his men to go home despite their willingness to fight, potentially missing an opportunity to strengthen his forces.
Saves Lord Bottoms from an archer's deadly shot despite Bottoms being an enemy.
Orders that Lord Bottoms be given a horse and spared, instructing that all who have yielded be spared and sent back to England.
Shows grief and respect for Marion by refraining from allowing the defiled bride to shoot the arrow and by mourning deeply at her graveside.
Stops an archer from killing Lord Bottoms by physically grabbing his fingers, showing quick reflexes and control in a tense moment.
Commands that Lord Bottoms be given a horse and orders the use of a less valuable horse, demonstrating strategic thinking and leadership.
Declares himself openly and confidently, refusing to hide his identity, showing courage and self-assurance.
Spares the defeated English soldiers and sends them back with a clear message, showing confidence and strategic mercy to strengthen morale and political position.
Shows grief and emotional vulnerability at Marion's grave, withdrawing personal mementos, indicating emotional depth but not directly related to competence.
Kneels at the graveside in unspeakable grief, carefully places the bloodstained strip over his daughter's heart and returns the handkerchief to his own heart.
Fights with passion and inspires men despite lacking knighthood.
His house and family graves are destroyed by enemies, showing he is a target of ruthless cruelty.
Suddenly appears to rescue comrades by attacking enemy soldiers with fire, showing bravery and protection.
Thanks Hamish quietly and accepts his support, showing gratitude and sincere friendship.
Leads the effort to secretly rebury Marion, showing respect and care for the deceased.
Welcomes new volunteers who come to fight for him, responds humbly by telling Faudron to stand up and not treat him like a pope.
Accepts a gift of a family tartan scarf from Faudron and asks to thank his wife, showing appreciation and respect.
Draws battle plans thoughtfully and shares concerns about the enemy's cavalry, showing care for his people's safety.
Calls Stephen 'my friend, Irishman' and affirms he will fight alongside him.
Grins and shows camaraderie in a tense moment with Stephen and Campbell.
Shakes his head and moves back to the fire, allowing newcomers to find their own spaces without interference.
Leads a timely charge to surround and ambush the English, showing leadership and care for his men.
Orders his men to stop and rest, allowing them to recover after battle.
Leads a well-timed ambush that traps the English in a bog, demonstrating tactical awareness and leadership.
Commands his men to stop and rest after the successful ambush, showing practical judgment and care for his troops' wellbeing.
Expresses deep love and longing for Marion sincerely in a vulnerable moment.
Listens to Stephen's advice and agrees to split the group to evade enemies, prioritizing group's survival.
Listens to Stephen's advice about splitting up to evade hounds and immediately implements the tactic, directing men to divide and run in different directions.
Despite splitting up multiple times, the group is still pursued relentlessly by hounds, indicating the tactic is not fully effective.
Stops to catch breath and acknowledges the danger to his group, showing concern.
Realizes someone betrayed him by giving his scent to the dogs, indicating trust issues but no direct blame or anger shown here.
Pulls out his dagger, presumably to protect himself or others, showing readiness to defend.
Faudron sacrifices himself, wearing Wallace's scarf, indicating Wallace inspires loyalty and trust from his companions.
Realizes the dogs are tracking his scent and deduces someone betrayed him by giving the scent to the dogs.
Stops running despite the danger, showing hesitation and panic as the dogs close in.
Pulls out his dagger in a desperate moment, possibly to create a diversion or defend himself.
Joins Stephen and Hamish in a fierce, wild attack to save each other, showing loyalty and camaraderie.
Laughs with companions after battle, showing a friendly and sincere bond.
Mentions distrust of English lord toward Irishman, indicating a wary or distrustful attitude toward others.
Stares into the trees where he saw Marion in his dream, suggesting a moment of tenderness or longing.
Fights to avenge a woman he loved, carries her body to a secret place after a trap.
Fights fiercely to avenge his lover after she is killed, showing determination and combat skill.
Successfully fights through an ambush set at his wife's grave and carries her body to a secret place, demonstrating tactical awareness and resilience.
Rides among the people who cheer him, inspiring common folk to join the fight, showing connection and trust with the community.
Asks if the nobles will rally, showing concern for unity and collective effort.
Rides into a deserting mob to confront them and inspire them to stay and fight.
Addresses both nobles and common soldiers with respect and sincerity, thanking nobles for their presence and questioning their loyalty to the army.
Shows no disdain or arrogance despite nobles' laughter and condescension, maintaining a composed and sincere demeanor.
Rides boldly into a mob of deserting soldiers to confront nobles and rally the troops.
Questions the nobles' authority and challenges their leadership in front of the army.
Appears awed and uncertain when looking at the large, disorganized army and receives no advice from his friends.
Raises his hand to silence the army and addresses them with humor and sincerity, inspiring unity and courage.
Speaks openly about his personal loss (his wife) to connect with his men.
Encourages soldiers to fight for freedom despite overwhelming odds, appealing to their sense of honor and shared sacrifice.
Draws his sword and leads by example, showing commitment and solidarity with his men.
Offers harsh terms to the English army, demanding they beg forgiveness for past atrocities or face death.
Orders his men to moon the English army, mocking the enemy with a bold, irreverent gesture.
Commands his men to break out new 14-foot spears and positions spearmen strategically on the far side of the bridge, showing tactical preparation.
Orders his men to moon the English army, using psychological tactics to provoke the enemy.
Does not immediately engage the English cavalry despite their uncontested crossing, maintaining formation and discipline.
Despite the English heavy cavalry crossing uncontested and forming up, Wallace remains calm and does not panic.
Calms and organizes his men to hold steady against the cavalry charge, demonstrating leadership and concern for their safety.
Leads his swordsmen out to attack the remaining knights after the charge, showing courage and solidarity with his men.
Commands the Scots to hold steady and form a spear wall against the cavalry charge, successfully neutralizing the knights' momentum.
Leads his swordsmen out after the cavalry charge to finish off surviving knights, showing tactical follow-through and leadership.
Smiles confidently before battle and uses a clever ruse to mislead the enemy, showing trust in his men and strategic kindness.
Leads his men courageously into battle, inspiring loyalty and camaraderie.
Leads a fierce charge against the English, fighting alongside his men with determination and courage.
Kills enemy soldiers ruthlessly during battle, showing no mercy.
Is lifted on the shoulders of his men in celebration after victory, showing camaraderie and mutual respect.
Fingers the cloth given by Marion, showing a sincere emotional connection and tenderness.
Observes the aftermath of battle with a somber awareness of the bloodshed and loss.
Leads a victorious battle against the English, inspiring Scottish soldiers and nobles alike.
Is knighted by an ancient elder, recognized publicly for his achievements and leadership.
Observes the aftermath of battle calmly and takes in the moment of triumph with confidence.
Fingers the cloth given by Marion, showing a moment of personal distraction amid public success.
Drapes golden chains of office around his friends' necks after receiving his own, sharing honor and recognition.
Acknowledges Robert the Bruce with respect and recalls his father's support for Bruce's family, showing loyalty and sincerity.
Turns his back and walks toward the door amid nobles' bickering, avoiding engagement in petty disputes.
Accepts the role of High Protector of Scotland with confidence and dignity, distributing chains of office to his captains, demonstrating leadership and awareness of symbolic gestures.
Focuses his attention on Robert the Bruce, recognizing a potential ally and showing political insight and strategic thinking.

Turns his back and walks toward the door amid the nobles' bickering, possibly indicating frustration or refusal to engage in petty disputes, which could be seen as either a confident dismissal or a failure to manage political conflict.
Speaks passionately about freedom and the responsibility of nobles to serve the people, not themselves.
Bashes succession documents into nobles' laps to emphasize his point, showing forcefulness but also sincerity.
Dismisses the nobles' concerns and walks away abruptly, showing impatience and possible intolerance.
Acknowledges the risks common men take on the battlefield, showing empathy and fairness.
Rejects compromise with nobles and insists on his own path, potentially alienating allies.
Encourages Robert the Bruce by emphasizing courage over noble titles and expresses willingness to follow him toward freedom.
Walks away after speaking to Robert the Bruce, leaving him alone to consider his words.
Rallies his men to break the gate by personally grabbing the battering ram and leading the charge.
Shouts to his men to wait for the fire to burn through the debris before advancing, showing tactical patience and care.
Stops his men from attacking prematurely despite the provocation of hanged Scots being thrown over the wall, showing restraint and leadership.
Declares they will be more merciful than the enemy, sparing women, children, and priests.
Rushes forward to help break the gate by grabbing the ram cart and rallying attackers, then uses a torch to burn the debris blocking the gate, showing tactical problem-solving and leadership.
Freezes momentarily and shows a boyhood reaction when the English throw hanged Scots over the wall, indicating a momentary emotional vulnerability.
Quickly recovers from shock to command his men to hold their position and interpret the enemy's actions as psychological warfare, demonstrating situational awareness and emotional control.
Declares a clear and strategic code of conduct for his men (mercy to non-combatants, no mercy to others), showing leadership and moral clarity.
Leads the charge through the burning barrier, screaming.
Leads the charge through the burning barrier, screaming and showing boldness in battle.
Warily approaches the royal entourage, prepared for ambush but does not act aggressively without cause.
Observes the Princess carefully and respectfully, noting her demeanor and responding to her curtsey.
Focuses on battle rather than engaging in diplomatic talk despite the Princess's respectful approach.
Prepares cautiously for a potential ambush by surrounding the tent and resting hand on sword handle, showing readiness and wariness.
Engages directly and confidently with the Princess, maintaining composure despite emotional distraction caused by her resemblance to Marion.
Focuses on his objective by stating he wants battle, not talk, demonstrating clarity of purpose and decisiveness.
Refuses the chair offered by the Princess, showing pride and anger.
Defends his actions as necessary retaliation against atrocities committed by the enemy.
Speaks honestly and directly to the Princess, refusing to lie even when challenged.
Turns away his men to have a private conversation with the princess, showing respect for privacy and sincerity.
Rejects the princess's offer of lordship and gold, calling it betrayal and slavery, showing integrity and passionate defense of his people.
Shares deeply personal and painful information about his late wife and her murder, revealing vulnerability and trust.
Expresses strong anger and uses harsh words ('Slaves are made in such ways!'), which may be seen as intense but sincere rather than cold or hostile.
Fluently speaks Latin and French to assert intelligence and confidence.
Refuses a bribe and title, showing principled and strategic thinking rather than short-term gain.
Expresses passionate outburst against slavery and oppression, demonstrating strong conviction and leadership.
Shares personal tragic story to build emotional connection and motivate the princess, showing emotional intelligence and strategic communication.
Nods for his men to leave to allow private conversation, showing situational awareness and control.
Accepts the Princess' gift for orphans without personal gain.
Shares a meaningful, silent moment of eye contact with the Princess.
Gives a non-committal shrug when observed by Hamish, avoiding emotional display.
Reins horse away quietly after the Princess' departure, showing restraint.
Maintains a calm, non-committal demeanor when observed by his captain, showing controlled confidence.
Chooses to wait and not advance or attack towns, demonstrating strategic patience and confidence in his plan.
Does not respond directly to the Princess' gift or engage in political manipulation, focusing instead on his cause.
No indication of rash or impulsive behavior; he reins his horse away calmly after the Princess leaves.
Welcomes Nicolette, a French rider, and allows her close despite the tense situation.
Gathers nobles for a demonstration, involving others in his plans.
Demonstrates the use of a crossbow effectively in front of nobles, showing skill and confidence.
Prepares his army to march and remains alert to approaching riders, showing situational awareness.
Warns nobles honestly about the threat they face and the scale of the enemy's power.
Expresses frustration and anger at nobles for their cowardice and lack of support, almost provoking violence.
Shows sincere desire for a united Scotland and appeals to Robert the Bruce to become king for the good of the country.
Encourages Robert by affirming his inner strength and potential.
Jokes about introducing dogs to the enemy after being hunted.
Encourages Stephen despite his shame about Irish troops fighting for the English, showing understanding of harsh realities.
Reassures Stephen and accepts his loyalty, fostering camaraderie.
Focuses on battle strategy and scanning the battlefield, showing leadership but limited emotional expression here.
Commands the release of war dogs to protect his troops and disrupt the enemy.
Signals cavalry to charge at a critical moment, showing trust in his forces.
Observes Mornay's betrayal and the abandonment of the Scottish army with visible agony.
Mornay betrays the army by withdrawing cavalry despite Wallace's orders.
Protects Hamish and his wounded father, commands Hamish to get his father to safety, fights fiercely to defend his men.
Fights valiantly to rally and protect his men despite being wounded.
Momentarily freezes upon seeing Robert the Bruce's guilt-ridden face, showing understanding and emotional depth.
Does not react to being wounded in the neck, focusing on the battle and his men rather than himself.
Comforts Hamish by telling him old Campbell was like a father to him.
Helps Hamish and Stephen carry old Campbell despite the defeat and chaos.
Removes the chain of office and lays it down before nobles, then walks out silently.
Helps carry wounded men and shows compassion to old Campbell, speaking with respect and emotional strength.
Removes the chain of office and lays it on the table before walking out, demonstrating a confident and deliberate act signaling refusal or protest.
Does not engage in futile arguments with nobles, instead choosing to leave the room, showing strategic restraint and self-control.
Visits Marion's hidden grave, handles her cloth tenderly despite his own pain and harsh conditions.
Removes the chain of office from beneath his breastplate and lays it on the table, then leaves the room calmly despite the nobles' satisfaction.
Disappears from the castle corridor unexpectedly, avoiding capture or confrontation.
Visits Marion's hidden grave alone in the woods, showing emotional restraint despite harsh conditions and wounds.
Shows no tears or visible emotional breakdown despite grief and physical suffering.
Rides boldly into enemy castle to confront and kill Mornay, showing fearless commitment to his cause.
Rides up the circular stairs inside Mornay's castle on horseback, cutting down a guard and slashing Mornay down despite being pursued and trapped by guards.
Cleverly escapes capture by riding a blind horse through a window and swimming to shore, inspiring the Scottish people who chant his name.
Cleverly uses a blind horse to escape through a window and swims to safety, evading capture by enemy guards.
Moves to Hamish and Stephen and hugs them despite his isolation.
Draws his broadsword quickly when hearing a rustle, showing alertness and readiness.
Hugs Hamish and Stephen, showing emotional connection and trust in his allies.
Is drinking in silence, isolated and reflective at Marion's grove, showing emotional burden but also composure.
Declines whiskey but smiles for the first time in weeks, showing appreciation and camaraderie.
Hands Hamish his sword before approaching the barn, indicating trust and respect.
Seals the barn door to trap assassins, enabling his men to ambush and burn them alive.
Climbs the castle wall stealthily to meet the Princess, showing trust and willingness to connect despite danger.
Acknowledges the Princess's signal and presence, showing attentiveness and sincerity.
Expresses self-deprecation ('I am much diminished since we met'), indicating vulnerability and openness.
Interrupts the Princess before she can share information about supplies, showing impatience or guardedness.
Climbs the castle wall hand over hand to reach a window twenty feet above the ground, showing physical skill and stealth.
Recognizes the meeting might be a trap and acknowledges only the princess would know he would be aware, showing situational awareness and intelligence.
Slips inside the castle quietly after the candle is extinguished, demonstrating careful timing and stealth.
Stops the princess from revealing information about the shipment, indicating control and strategic thinking.
Responds to the Princess's feelings with restraint and respect, acknowledging her vows and his own limits.
Shares an intimate moment with the Princess, showing vulnerability and connection.
Understands the Princess's complex situation and responds thoughtfully, showing emotional intelligence and self-control.
Engages in a secretive romantic encounter despite the political and personal complications, indicating a nuanced but risky decision.
Touches the princess's face in gratitude and kisses her sincerely before leaving.
Leads villagers and men in a relentless attack, inspiring cheers.
Declines Stephen's offer of drink to help sleep, showing self-control and consideration.
Stares silently at the fire, withdrawn and restless among friends.
Leads a successful attack on an English fortress with fifty men, showing relentlessness and inspiring villagers to follow him; fortress sacked and people cheering him.
Declines rest and drink offered by friends, indicating strong will but possibly ignoring his own physical limits.
Stirs up commoners from Highland clans to lowland villages, challenging nobles and Longshanks' rule.
Confronts nobles who have sworn allegiance to Longshanks, implying distrust of their loyalty.
Commands the respect and attention of nobles by leading guerrillas to confront them directly.
Challenges the nobles' loyalty by pointing out their oath to Longshanks is meaningless.
Is indirectly referenced as the embodiment of Scotland's crown and leadership, implying strong symbolic and practical authority.
Insists on Robert the Bruce's public oath to Scotland before meeting the nobles, showing commitment to unity and trustworthiness.
Shares his personal desires for home, children, and peace with Hamish, revealing sincerity and vulnerability.
Acknowledges the danger of the meeting but accepts it as necessary for collective success, showing responsibility and concern for others.
Rejects Hamish's accusation that his dreams are selfish, clarifying his true motivations and showing openness.
Insists on meeting only if Robert the Bruce swears loyalty publicly, showing strategic insistence on unity and legitimacy.
Acknowledges the possibility of a trap but accepts it as necessary to gain allies, demonstrating realistic and pragmatic decision-making.
Expresses personal desires for peace and family but accepts his role and duty, showing emotional intelligence and commitment.
Engages in a candid conversation with Hamish, addressing doubts and motivations openly, indicating self-awareness and leadership.
Hugs his friends Stephen and Hamish before riding away, showing emotional connection and care.
Arrives unarmed at Robert the Bruce's house, trusting him despite risk.
Stares at Robert the Bruce after being betrayed and captured, showing silent disappointment.
Hands over weapons to friends and rides alone unarmed into a trap, showing trust but lack of caution.
Rides alone unarmed into enemy territory, demonstrating bravery but poor tactical judgment.
Maintains composure and dignity when captured, showing inner strength and confidence.
Endures public jeering and physical abuse silently while being transported to execution.
Shows no visible anger or retaliation toward the jeering crowd.
Remains silent and stoic despite being jeered, physically abused, and parched during his capture and procession.
Is captured and restrained without apparent resistance or escape attempt.
Refuses to confess to treason despite threat of torture and death.
Prays alone in prison, admitting fear and asking for strength.
Refuses to confess to treason despite threat of torture and death, demonstrating strong resolve and clear understanding of his position.
Argues logically that he cannot commit treason if he never swore allegiance, showing intelligence and confidence.
Prays and admits fear while alone in prison, showing vulnerability but also seeking strength.
Does not attempt escape or resist jailers physically, possibly indicating acceptance or strategic patience.
Tries to comfort the princess by acknowledging her kindness and grief despite being a stranger.
Refuses to take the drug to dull his pain, showing resolve and respect for his own dignity.
Speaks sincerely about loyalty to his country and the cost of swearing allegiance to the king.
Refuses to swear allegiance to the king despite the promise of mercy, showing clear understanding of the political situation and maintaining his principles.
Rejects the pain-numbing drug to keep his wits sharp during torture, demonstrating self-control and strategic thinking.
Attempts to comfort and distract the princess despite his dire situation, showing emotional intelligence and presence of mind.
Is respected by the Princess as a worthy enemy, inspiring her to plead for his life.
Is captured and dragged to execution, indicating a failure to avoid capture or defeat.
Maintains eye contact with a former English soldier who threw a stone, piercing his soul and causing the soldier to look away in shame.
Refuses to beg for mercy or declare loyalty to the king despite imminent execution and crowd hostility.
Maintains piercing eye contact with a former enemy soldier, causing him shame and hesitation despite the hostile crowd.
Refuses to beg for mercy or declare loyalty to the king even when facing imminent execution and extreme pressure.
Is pale and trembling before execution, showing human vulnerability but does not break under pressure.
Makes a grim joke about the pain ('That... will... clear your sinuses.') despite extreme torture.
Despite extreme physical torture and pain, Wallace remains conscious, refuses to beg for mercy, and even makes a defiant, witty remark.
Screams 'FREEDOM' defiantly in the face of death, inspiring courage in others including friends and strangers.
Looks toward the crowd and sees loved ones with warmth and connection in his final moments.
Fights through pain and fear to scream 'Freedom' loudly and defiantly before execution, inspiring others.
Does not plead for mercy or show weakness even in the face of death, demonstrating strong resolve and confidence.
Inspires lasting loyalty and courage in others, as evidenced by the Highlanders chanting his name and fighting with fierce determination even after his death.
Does not appear directly in the scene to lead or act, but his legacy and influence are strong; no direct incompetence shown.
